NewWords.WordPhrase: together with 连同
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I took a friend along with me.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a feeling of worry or fear 忧虑，担心
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The increase in the tax on heating fuel is causing a lot of anxiety among elderly people.

NewWords.WordPhrase: feeling foolish or uncomfortable because of (sth.) 因…感到难为情
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She was so ashamed of cheating in the test that she went and told the teacher.

NewWords.WordPhrase: prove that (sth.) is true 证实
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His version of events just isn't borne out by the facts.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 健美运动员
n. 微风，轻风
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A gentle breeze was blowing.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 使回到现实中
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Jack had been spending all his time chatting on line with his key-pals until his parents had a word with him and brought him back to earth.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. happen at the same time; be in agreement 同时发生；一致  coincide with 与…同时发生；与…一致
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His arrival in Tokyo coincided with the beginning of the war.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 竞争者，对手
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The bank isn't performing as well as some of its competitors.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  祝贺
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His teachers congratulated him on winning the first prize in the speech contest.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the most important part 核心  hard-core a. 顽固不化的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The core of the problem is their objection to educational reform.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. small, particular fact or item 细节；琐碎的事
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. No details of the negotiation between the two countries have been revealed.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 鹰
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Eagles wheel in the sky.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. needing little or no effort 容易的，不费力气的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She plays with seemingly effortless skill.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 情感，感情
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Jack is a man of great emotion, easily given to tears.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 幻想
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I still have the fantasy that one day I will win the National Lottery.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. using or operated by the fingers 用手的
n. quality of being smooth and elegant , esp. in movement or structure 优美，优雅；雅致
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Classically trained dancers have an extraordinary grace of movement.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 体操家，体操运动员
n. 干草
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. My father is feeding the cattle on hay.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 在想象中
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. In his mind's eye, she is still a shy girl.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  the state of being intense 强烈，剧烈，紧张
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. In order to finish the job in time, we have to work with greater intensity.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  大众传播媒介
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They are wondering whether bias in the news media contributed to the candidate's defeat.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. nothing more than 仅仅，只不过
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. It's a mere 200 meters from my house to the college.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. very many 许多的，无数的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. During the Depression, numerous people wandered from town to town looking for work.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 有一（两，几）次
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. On several occasions, I attempted to talk with my parents about my parents about my taking a part-time job, but my mother instantly interrupted my by asking me questions about my studies.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  strong feeling, esp. of love 热情
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He loved her still, with the same passion as he always had.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the act or process of preparing 准备
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Banks have made adequate preparations for the introduction of the euro, the new common currency in 12 European countries.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a person who deals in a practical way with situations as they actually are 现实主义者
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Realists would agree with many of these criticisms.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. come or happen again 再来；再发生
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The theme of love recurred n many of his books.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. make or become less tense, worried or nervous 放松，松弛
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The best strategy for avoiding stress is to learn how to relax.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. give a sudden shock or surprise to 使大吃一惊
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. You startled me -- I didn't hear you come in.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 伸展
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She stretched out a hand to grab the child.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. 出汗  n. 汗水
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She was sweating as she reached the top of the hill.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 起跳；（飞机）起飞
a. feeling worried or nervous; making people worried or nervous 紧张的；令人紧张的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Facing so many teachers, John got very tense and made several mistakes in his recitation.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. worry or nervousness 紧张，不安
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. You could feel the tension in the room as we waited for our exam results.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 毛巾，手巾
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She dried the dishes with a clean towel.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. too pleased with one's own abilities or looks 虚荣的，自负的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Too much praise can make a person vain.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  举重（运动）
